articles.headline: The Accounting Tack That Makes PayPal’s Numbers Look So Good
articles.snippet: The digital payment giant doesn’t count the stock grants it gives to employees as an expense. This makes its earnings look prettier to Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The digital payment giant doesn’t count the stock grants it gives to employees as an expense. This makes its earnings look prettier to Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors liked what they saw in PayPal’s second-quarter financial results, reported by the digital and mobile payments giant on July 26. Revenues grew to $3.14 billion in the quarter that ended in June, an increase of 18 percent over the same period last year. Total payment volume of $106 billion was up 23 percent, year over year.

articles.headline: Now at Saks: Salt Rooms, a Bootcamp and a Peek at Retail’s Future
articles.snippet: As department stores try to lure back their customers, Saks Fifth Avenue has unveiled an assortment of wellness offerings at its flagship store in Manhattan.
articles.abstract: As department stores try to lure back their customers, Saks Fifth Avenue has unveiled an assortment of wellness offerings at its flagship store in Manhattan.
articles.lead_paragraph: I entered a neon-lit chamber the size of a phone booth and sat on the bench as instructed. Pink Himalayan salt bricks formed the walls, and pink salt crystals crunched beneath my shoes.

articles.headline: Martin Shkreli Is Found Guilty of Fraud
articles.snippet: The brash Mr. Shkreli, best known for increasing the price of a drug to $750 from $13.50 a pill overnight, was convicted by a federal jury in Brooklyn.
articles.abstract: The brash Mr. Shkreli, best known for increasing the price of a drug to $750 from $13.50 a pill overnight, was convicted by a federal jury in Brooklyn.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli, 34, has confidently courted controversy in recent years, bulldozing his way into Wall Street and the drug industry, raising the price of a lifesaving drug by 5,000 percent overnight, boasting that he would outwit prosecutors in his federal fraud case, and live-streaming and tweeting throughout his five-week trial.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Colin Moynihan

articles.headline: Macron Takes On France’s Labor Code, 100 Years in the Making
articles.snippet: The new French president’s boldest initiative is a bid to overhaul French capitalism. Just one thing may stand in his way: 3,324 pages of regulations.
articles.abstract: The new French president’s boldest initiative is a bid to overhaul French capitalism. Just one thing may stand in his way: 3,324 pages of regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — It is a mind-numbing 3,324 pages long and growing. Of those, 170 pages govern firings, 420 regulate health and security, 50 temporary work and 85 collective negotiations. Hundreds more are devoted to wages, specific industries and overseas departments.

articles.headline: Mueller Seeks White House Documents on Flynn
articles.snippet: Investigators have also questioned witnesses about whether Michael T. Flynn was secretly paid by the Turkish government in the final months of the 2016 presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: Investigators have also questioned witnesses about whether Michael T. Flynn was secretly paid by the Turkish government in the final months of the 2016 presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Investigators working for the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, recently asked the White House for documents related to the former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn, and have questioned witnesses about whether he was secretly paid by the Turkish government during the final months of the presidential campaign, according to people close to the investigation.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg, Matt Apuzzo and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: How This U.S. Tech Giant Is Backing China’s Tech Ambitions
articles.snippet: Qualcomm is providing the money, expertise and engineering to help drive Beijing’s master plan to create its own technology superpowers.
articles.abstract: Qualcomm is providing the money, expertise and engineering to help drive Beijing’s master plan to create its own technology superpowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Chinese government develops drones, the American technology giant Qualcomm is helping. The same goes for artificial intelligence, mobile technology and supercomputers. Qualcomm is also working to help Chinese companies like Huawei break into overseas markets in support of China’s “go global” campaign to develop big multinational brands.

articles.headline: In Weary Wisconsin Town, a Billionaire-Fueled Revival
articles.snippet: Diane Hendricks and her late husband saw opportunity in Beloit, a decaying industrial town. Now, she dreams of turning it into a mecca for start-ups.
articles.abstract: Diane Hendricks and her late husband saw opportunity in Beloit, a decaying industrial town. Now, she dreams of turning it into a mecca for start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELOIT, Wis. — When Diane Hendricks sees something she doesn’t like here, she buys it.

articles.headline: In Afghanistan, U.S. Exits, and Iran Comes In
articles.snippet: Tehran’s accelerating campaign to exert influence threatens to undo 16 years and half a trillion dollars’ worth of American efforts to forge a stable democratic Afghan government.
articles.abstract: Tehran’s accelerating campaign to exert influence threatens to undo 16 years and half a trillion dollars’ worth of American efforts to forge a stable democratic Afghan government.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARAH, Afghanistan — A police officer guarding the outskirts of this city remembers the call from his commander, warning that hundreds of Taliban fighters were headed his way.

articles.headline: North Korean Defector, ‘Treated Like Dirt’ in South, Fights to Return
articles.snippet: Disenchanted with life in capitalist South Korea, Kwon Chol-nam is asking to be repatriated, an impossibility under current law.
articles.abstract: Disenchanted with life in capitalist South Korea, Kwon Chol-nam is asking to be repatriated, an impossibility under current law.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Divorced and out of money, Kwon Chol-nam fled North Korea for China in 2014 by wading across a river border at night and then crawling over a barbed-wire fence. After a perilous trek that included walking through a jungle in Laos, he reached Thailand, where he was allowed to fly to South Korea to start a new life.

articles.headline: Republican Shadow Campaign for 2020 Takes Shape as Trump Doubts Grow
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump’s presidency may only be warming up, but in public and private, Republicans are maneuvering for his job, whether or not he runs for re-election.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump’s presidency may only be warming up, but in public and private, Republicans are maneuvering for his job, whether or not he runs for re-election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators Tom Cotton and Ben Sasse have already been to Iowa this year, Gov. John Kasich is eyeing a return visit to New Hampshire, and Mike Pence’s schedule is so full of political events that Republicans joke that he is acting more like a second-term vice president hoping to clear the field than a No. 2 sworn in a little over six months ago.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Affirmative Action Policies Evolve, Achieving Their Own Diversity
articles.snippet: The practice in college admissions has evolved from race-based quotas of decades ago into a range of approaches that only occasionally produce the desired results.
articles.abstract: The practice in college admissions has evolved from race-based quotas of decades ago into a range of approaches that only occasionally produce the desired results.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a year ago, after the Supreme Court rejected a challenge to the University of Texas at Austin’s admissions program by a single swing vote, the question seemed to be edging, at last, toward an answer: Colleges could, the justices ruled, consider race when deciding whom to let through their gates.

articles.headline: When Foreign Companies Are Making, Not Killing, U.S. Jobs
articles.snippet: The Chattanooga region has become a magnet for investment from overseas, helping drive Tennessee’s unemployment to a record low.
articles.abstract: The Chattanooga region has become a magnet for investment from overseas, helping drive Tennessee’s unemployment to a record low.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — At the airport here, there is a reminder to travelers of the jobs that global trade can bring. A shiny 2017 Volkswagen Passat is stationed near the entryway and labeled: “Designed in Germany. Built in Chattanooga.”

articles.headline: Under Trump, Coal Mining Gets New Life on U.S. Lands
articles.snippet: A business-friendly secretary of the interior has moved to invigorate a struggling industry, reversing Obama-era restrictions to help create “wealth and jobs.”
articles.abstract: A business-friendly secretary of the interior has moved to invigorate a struggling industry, reversing Obama-era restrictions to help create “wealth and jobs.”
articles.lead_paragraph: DECKER, Mont. — The Trump administration is wading into one of the oldest and most contentious debates in the West by encouraging more coal mining on lands owned by the federal government. It is part of an aggressive push to both invigorate the struggling American coal industry and more broadly exploit commercial opportunities on public lands.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Barry Meier

articles.headline: Political Donors Put Their Money Where the Memes Are
articles.snippet: Funding is flowing into social media, where partisan organizations are specializing in creating viral messages to reach voters.
articles.abstract: Funding is flowing into social media, where partisan organizations are specializing in creating viral messages to reach voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re a millionaire or billionaire with strong political views and a desire to spread those views to the masses. Do you start a think tank in Washington? Funnel millions to a shadowy “super PAC”? Bankroll the campaign of an up-and-coming politician?

articles.headline: Diplomats Question Tactics of Tillerson, the Executive Turned Secretary of State
articles.snippet: A spokesman for Rex W. Tillerson said the former Exxon Mobil chief had found many problems at the State Department, but critics say he is not focusing on the most pressing issues.
articles.abstract: A spokesman for Rex W. Tillerson said the former Exxon Mobil chief had found many problems at the State Department, but critics say he is not focusing on the most pressing issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Several times a week the State Department sends a greeting to a foreign country on the occasion of its national day. By tradition, the salutations have been written by low-level diplomats and routinely approved by their superiors.

articles.headline: Countering West Coast Pull, by Helping Finance Start-Ups Sell in New York
articles.snippet: The FinTech Innovation Lab, a New York business-backed program, has been working to help financial-services start-ups sell their services in New York.
articles.abstract: The FinTech Innovation Lab, a New York business-backed program, has been working to help financial-services start-ups sell their services in New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jeff Bezos, then a New York hedge fund employee, decided to start Amazon in 1994, he quickly moved to the West Coast. So did Mark Zuckerberg, who moved from Harvard to California in 2004 to find the technology talent and financing needed to build up Facebook.

articles.headline: In a Corporate Concert World, an Indie Thrives in Washington
articles.snippet: The promoter Seth Hurwitz has succeeded by creating high-quality venues and catering to artists’ needs. His latest undertaking is no exception.
articles.abstract: The promoter Seth Hurwitz has succeeded by creating high-quality venues and catering to artists’ needs. His latest undertaking is no exception.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a recent tour of the Anthem, his $60 million concert hall under construction, Seth Hurwitz excitedly pointed out the room’s features as they took shape. A movable stage. Angled balconies. An outside terrace with a striking waterfront vista.

articles.headline: Weaning Itself From Elephant Ivory, China Turns to Mammoths
articles.snippet: Promoters of ivory from the extinct animals say it’s an ethical alternative. Others fear it may give cover to the black-market elephant ivory trade.
articles.abstract: Promoters of ivory from the extinct animals say it’s an ethical alternative. Others fear it may give cover to the black-market elephant ivory trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: NANJING, China — Environmentalists worried about the fate of Africa’s dwindling elephant population cheered when China announced a ban on the sale of commercial ivory last year, but an increasingly popular substitute is raising concerns of its own.

articles.headline: U.S. Troops Train in Eastern Europe to Echoes of the Cold War
articles.snippet: A 10-day exercise in July offered a window into how Army commanders are rehearsing updated tactics and strategies once used to counter Soviet troops.
articles.abstract: A 10-day exercise in July offered a window into how Army commanders are rehearsing updated tactics and strategies once used to counter Soviet troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOVO SELO TRAINING RANGE, Bulgaria — After more than a decade spent fighting Islamic insurgents in Iraq and Afghanistan, the United States Army is scrambling to relearn Cold War-era skills to confront potential threats from Russia here in Eastern Europe, territory formerly defended by the Soviet Army.

articles.headline: Sprint, Looking to Get Bigger to Survive, Weighs Deal-Making
articles.snippet: The company and its backer, SoftBank, have had talks with both Charter and T-Mobile to improve its fortunes as it falls behind rivals.
articles.abstract: The company and its backer, SoftBank, have had talks with both Charter and T-Mobile to improve its fortunes as it falls behind rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Masayoshi Son, the Japanese telecommunications mogul, has always been known as an inveterate deal maker. But amid a breakneck spree of investing in start-ups, Mr. Son’s most anticipated moves will likely involve an old-line phone service provider: Sprint.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Shown the Door, Older Workers Find Bias Hard to Prove
articles.snippet: Many longtime workers claim that they are being targeted for layoffs because of their age or health status, but federal law is often of little help.
articles.abstract: Many longtime workers claim that they are being targeted for layoffs because of their age or health status, but federal law is often of little help.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, manufacturing was the only work Donetta Raymond knew.

articles.headline: Trump’s Stalled Trade Agenda Leaves Industries in the Lurch
articles.snippet: Workers and industry groups say they aren’t tired of winning. They are tired of waiting for action.
articles.abstract: Workers and industry groups say they aren’t tired of winning. They are tired of waiting for action.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump promised Americans that they would be exhausted from “winning” on trade under his presidency. But nearly seven months after Mr. Trump took office, the industries he vowed to protect have become tired of something else: waiting.
